      <title>Prince Charles: I use homeopathy in animals to cut antibiotic use</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/12/prince-charles-use-homeopathy-in-animals-to-cut-antibiotic-use</link>
      <description><p>Homeopathy sceptic Dame Sally Davies among delegates to hear prince say he treats his cows with alternative medicine</p><p>Prince Charles has proposed a solution to the growing crisis of antibiotic over-use in animals and humans, telling an international gathering of scientists and government officials in London that he treats his own cows and sheep with homeopathy.</p><p>In front of the government’s chief medical officer, Dame Sally Davies, who once told a parliamentary committee that <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2014/may/08/jeremy-hunt-homeopathy-studies-chief-medical-officer">homeopathy in humans was “rubbish”</a> and that she was “perpetually surprised that homeopathy is available on the NHS”, the prince explained to delegates from 20 nations and organisations why he had turned to homeopathic remedies for animals.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/12/prince-charles-use-homeopathy-in-animals-to-cut-antibiotic-use">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>'If you don't talk, it doesn't work': how sport helps autistic people</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/12/how-sport-helps-autistic-people-effective-treatment-autism</link>
      <description><p>The intrinsic importance of social skills in sport means it can be a more effective treatment than traditional therapy</p><p> “A few years ago, I couldn’t even go out of the house by myself,” says Daniel Mynott. That was before he started getting involved in sport. “Now, I go all over London and the country. I have so many friends I’ve lost count. I even have my own car.”</p><p>Mynott has autism. A few years ago, when he was 15, <a href="http://www.thechangefoundation.org.uk/">the Change Foundation</a> turned up at his school and encouraged him to try taking part in sport. “I hated sport,” he says. “I was lazy as hell, but they saw my potential, they saw I was good with people. Gradually, I fell in love with it.”<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/12/how-sport-helps-autistic-people-effective-treatment-autism">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Turmeric latte: the ‘golden milk’ with a cult following</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/11/turmeric-latte-golden-milk-cult-following-alternative-coffee</link>
      <description><p>Cafes from Sydney to San Francisco are spicing up their menus with cold-pressed turmeric juice added to almond, cashew or coconut milk. It’s a healthy alternative to coffee, it tastes great – and it’s easy to make your own</p><p>It is a drink fit for Midas, with an ochre colour so vivid it doesn’t need an Instagram filter. It’s not made of gold, but it might as well be, given its cult following. “Golden milk” or turmeric latte – an unlikely combination of nut milk and juiced turmeric root – is 2016’s drink of choice. In a new report on food trends in the US, Google singled out turmeric’s ascent after searches for the spice increased <a href="https://www.thinkwithgoogle.com/articles/2016-food-trends-google.html">by 56% from November 2015 to January 2016</a>. And fuelling that rise is its use in lattes: “golden milk” is among the top online searches associated with the spice. Turmeric lattes are now being sold at cafes from Sydney to San Francisco, and the drink is gaining fans in the UK.</p><p>At <a href="http://modernbaker.com">Modern Baker in Summertown, Oxford</a>, sales of turmeric lattes – listed on the menu as “Golden mylk” (the “y” is health-speak for non-cow milk) now outnumber that of regular lattes. Turmeric lattes routinely feature in reviews for the York outpost of the <a href="http://www.filmoreandunion.com/">Filmore &amp; Union</a> restaurant chain. <a href="http://namafoods.com">Nama, a vegan restaurant in Notting Hill, west London,</a> has noticed a surge in the turmeric latte’s popularity recently, even though it has sold the drink for nearly two years. A prescient former employee used to whip them up for the staff, and they went down so well that the latte ended up on the menu. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/11/turmeric-latte-golden-milk-cult-following-alternative-coffee">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Aquajogging: how, when and why to try it</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/the-running-blog/2016/may/11/aquajogging-how-when-and-why-to-try-it</link>
      <description><p>Kelly Holmes and other athletes find jogging underwater perfect for staying fit without impacting the legs – and it might even improve your form on land</p><p>Injuries happen to all runners regardless of age, ability or experience. Aquajogging, otherwise known as deepwater running, is a great way of staying fit while injured. </p><p>The double Olympic champion Kelly Holmes was an early proponent. In 2000, Holmes suffered a calf injury and could only resume track training six weeks before the Sydney Olympics, where she won the bronze medal. This remarkable achievement was made possible by her use of aquajogging to maintain an extremely high level of fitness as the injury healed.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/the-running-blog/2016/may/11/aquajogging-how-when-and-why-to-try-it">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Sandwiches are toast: why we swapped sliced bread for wraps and salads</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/09/sandwiches-toast-swapped-sliced-bread-wraps-salads</link>
      <description><p>Sales of packaged loaves are down as consumers turn to alternative breads – or avoid baked goods altogether. Is this the end of the packed lunch?</p><p>Next time someone tells you something is the best thing since sliced bread, you might want to take it with a generous pinch of salt. According to data from market analysts Kantar Worldpanel, nearly 80 years after it first hit the shelves in this country, we’re falling out of love with the ready-wrapped loaf – sales are down by 50m units over the last 12 months, despite the fact that it has never been cheaper.</p><p>Bread is often at the frontline of price cuts as retailers attempt to lure customers back with discounted basics. But although the average price of a loaf dropped from 98p to 90p in 2015, it seems that is just not enough to tempt us back. Sales had been in slow decline for decades, but it was the Atkins diet, a radical weightloss plan based on a low-carb regime, whose popularity peaked in Britain in the early noughties, that sent them into freefall.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/09/sandwiches-toast-swapped-sliced-bread-wraps-salads">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Break the period taboo: my name is Lindy West and I bleed</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/09/break-period-taboo-lindy-west-book-shrill</link>
      <description><p>In this second exclusive extract from her new book, Shrill, West dares to imagine a world where girls feel free to talk about menstruation in shouts instead of whispers</p><ul><li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/08/perfect-body-lie-believed-long-time-let-shrink-my-life-lindy-west">The ‘perfect body’ is a lie. I believed it for a long time and let it shrink my life</a></li></ul><p>When you’re a little kid, everyone talks about your period like it’s going to be a party bus to WOOOOOOOOOO! Mountain. It’s all romantic metaphors about “blossoming gardens” and “unfurling crotch orchids”, and kids buy into it because they don’t know what a euphemism is because they are 11. But it’s also a profoundly secret thing – a confidence for closed-door meetings between women. Those two contradictory approaches (“periods are the best!” and “we must never ever speak of them”), made me feel as if I was the only not-brainwashed one in a culty dystopian novel. “Oh, yes, you can’t imagine the joy readings in your subjectivity port when the Administration gifts you your woman’s flow! SPEAKING OF THE FLOW OUTSIDE OF THE MENARCHE BUNKER WILL RESULT IN DEACTIVATION.”</p><p>The reality, of course, is that when you hit puberty you don’t magically blossom into a woman – you’re still the same tiny fool you were at puberty-minus-one, only now, once a month, hot brown blood just glops and glops out of your private area like a broken Slurpee machine. For ever. Or, at least, until you’re inconceivably elderly, in an 11-year-old’s estimation. Don’t worry, to deal, you just have to cork up your hole with this thing that’s like a severed toe made out of cotton (and if you don’t swap it out often enough, your legs fall off and you die). Or you wear a diaper. Also, your uterus is knives and you poop a bunch and you’re hormonal and you get acne. Have fun in sixth grade, Margaret.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/09/break-period-taboo-lindy-west-book-shrill">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>How was your weekend running?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/the-running-blog/2016/may/09/how-was-your-weekend-running</link>
      <description><p>Running at night or running in the heat of the day? As always come and share your weekend’s exploits below the line</p><p><br>Standing at the start line of a race when you have absolutely no idea what’s going on or what anyone is saying (except that they’re clearly very excited) is somewhat disorientating. Add in that it’s 8pm, pitch dark and somewhere on the shores of a huge lake in Japan and you can see why I vaguely wondered if I was dreaming. After about a mile of the race, we made a right turn and looking back, at a winding stream of headlights blinking across a narrow path between fields, to the sound of the loudest insects I’ve ever heard, and I was almost sure I was.</p><p>This was the Japan leg of the Wings for Life World Run, a race I somehow managed to win in the UK last year. Given the incredible distances reached by the Japanese winners – and others across the world – before they were “caught” by the catcher car, I wouldn’t have stood a chance this year, so I decided to get to about 15 miles, easy pace, then jog. In fact, it turns out that 10 miles of walking around stunning Kyoto earlier in the day makes even easy pace seem hard very early on, and with the humidity, I was struggling by 10 miles. I got to 15 and stopped, waiting for the car and enjoying the sight of those bob of headlights streaming towards me. You might see more by day, but night-time running like this is an incredible experience.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/the-running-blog/2016/may/09/how-was-your-weekend-running">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>City planners tap into wealth of cycling data from Strava tracking app</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/09/city-planners-cycling-data-strava-tracking-app</link>
      <description><p>Seventy-six cities and regions are using Strava Metro data to help assess and shape transport policy</p><p>Sheila Lyons recalls the way Oregon used to collect data on how many people rode bikes. “It was very haphazard, two-hour counts done once a year,” said the woman in charge of cycling policy for the state government. “Volunteers, sitting on the street corner because they wanted better bike facilities. Pathetic, really.”</p><p>But in 2013 a colleague had an idea. She recorded her own bike rides using an app called <a href="https://www.strava.com/">Strava</a>, and thought: why not ask the company to share its data? And so was born <a href="http://metro.strava.com/">Strava Metro</a>, both an inadvertent tech business spinoff and a similarly accidental urban planning tool, one that is now quietly helping to reshape streets in more than 70 places around the world and counting.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/09/city-planners-cycling-data-strava-tracking-app">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Can mindfulness help ease back pain?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/09/can-mindfulness-help-ease-back-pain-mbsr</link>
      <description><p>Each year, 10m working days are lost due to backache. So could mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) play a part in reducing that figure?</p><p>When I was a junior doctor, I dreaded the back pain clinic. You had a few minutes with each patient to talk through their months of debilitating pain. There was little to offer in terms of relief. Fast forward and back pain is only getting worse. A report from the University of Washington in Seattle found that while people live longer, they feel healthy for fewer years because of backache. So what can help relieve pain and reduce the annual <a href="http://www.express.co.uk/news/uk/583948/back-pain-experts" title="">10m days lost from work each year in the UK due to backache</a>?</p><p>It depends on the cause, but exercise, spinal manipulation and painkillers such as codeine (a weak opiod) and paracetamol are often recommended. Taking&nbsp;opiods for years can make people dependent and invariably causes constipation. Guidance from Nice, which is being updated, also <a href="http://www.nhs.uk/Conditions/Back-pain/Pages/Treatment.aspx" title="">recommends cognitive behavioural therapy</a> (CBT) – training to change how people think and behave when they have pain, which is&nbsp;notoriously hard to come by.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/09/can-mindfulness-help-ease-back-pain-mbsr">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The ‘perfect body’ is a lie. I believed it for a long time and let it shrink my life</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/08/perfect-body-lie-believed-long-time-let-shrink-my-life-lindy-west</link>
      <description><p>As a child, Lindy West was told she was ‘off the charts’. In this exclusive extract from her new book, Shrill, she explains how society’s fixation on thinness warps women’s lives – and why she would rather be ‘fat’ than ‘big’</p><p>I’ve always been a great big person. In the months after I was born, the doctor was so alarmed by the circumference of my head that she insisted my parents bring me back, over and over, to be weighed and measured and held up for scrutiny next to the “normal” babies. My head was “off the charts”, she said. Science literally had not produced a chart expansive enough to account for my monster dome. “Off the charts” became a West family joke over the years – I always deflected it, saying it was because of my giant brain – but I absorbed the message nonetheless. I was too big, from birth. Abnormally big. Medical-anomaly big. Unchartably big.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/08/perfect-body-lie-believed-long-time-let-shrink-my-life-lindy-west">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Blood testing for amateur runners: is it worth it?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/the-running-blog/2016/may/04/blood-testing-for-amateur-runners</link>
      <description><p>New technology offers more and more data on performance, even for amateurs. But is blood testing just a path to worry, and potentially worse? </p><p>Six months of waiting. A year of training. Perhaps a lifetime of dreaming. The race is finally underway, yet you feel rundown and lacklustre. There is a <a href="http://bmjopensem.bmj.com/content/1/1/e000063.full">scientific term</a> for it, but let’s just call it a bad race day. Everyone has experienced it, from Paula Radcliffe to yours faithfully (occasional amateur).<br></p><p>The next generation of running technology, and in particular more accessible blood testing, promises to help avoid such frustrating and unexplained dips in performance. We can monitor our heart rates and sleep, but within five years we could have instant access to a whole range of data linked to physical performance, including red blood cell count and vitamin D and iron levels.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/the-running-blog/2016/may/04/blood-testing-for-amateur-runners">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>How was your weekend running?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/the-running-blog/2016/may/02/how-was-your-weekend-running</link>
      <description><p>Ever been chased down by a driver in a race? Sounds nightmarish, but it’s what awaits Wings for Life World Run participants. Share your weekend woes and triumphs below the line.</p><p>It feels a bit like cheating, but in the interests of full disclosure, I’m writing this before the weekend. On Saturday, I’m off to Japan – for a holiday and to do the <a href="http://www.wingsforlifeworldrun.com/gb/en/?utm_source=google&amp;utm_medium=cpc&amp;utm_term=wings%20for%20life%20world%20run&amp;utm_campaign=">Wings for Life World Run</a>. That being so, I’m tempted to invent a fantasy weekend of running: 5k PB at parkrun on Saturday, 10km PB on Sunday, recovery run Sunday evening sound good? Oh, OK then, I’ll be squeezing in a quick track session on Saturday morning before sitting on a plane for 12 hours and trying not to go out of my mind with boredom.</p><p>Instead, then, a brief explainer of the Wings for Life run, which doesn’t seem very well known, but which I cannot recommend highly enough. The basic principle is that everyone starts at the same time at the locations around the world, regardless of time zone. A catcher car starts half an hour later, and very gradually speeds up. You are “out” when the car passes you. The result is that, unlike in most races, the fastest people run the longest. When you are “caught” you head back to HQ to watch the action unfold on a big screen. It’s unlike any other race I’ve done, and the fact that the Japanese edition takes place in the dark in, for me, totally unfamiliar terrain, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/the-running-blog/2015/may/04/how-was-your-weekend-running">should make it even more surreal than my experience last year</a>. Full report to follow next Monday.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/the-running-blog/2016/may/02/how-was-your-weekend-running">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>'Today we die a little' – writing the story of Emil Zátopek</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/the-running-blog/2016/apr/27/today-we-die-a-little-writing-the-story-of-emil-zatopek</link>
      <description><p>Richard Askwith talks about the difficulty and the joy of writing a biography of one of the greatest runners of all time, from grappling with the legends to capturing the spirit of a truly unique man</p><p>I think of Zátopek as the patron saint of runners. He didn’t just revolutionise his sport – he reinvented it. He rewrote the record books and redrew the boundaries of endurance, redefining the whole idea of what was humanly possible. No one else, before or since, has dominated distance running in a way that he did in the late 1940s and early 1950s. His <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2012/jun/22/50-olympic-stunning-moments-emil-zatopek">achievements at the Helsinki Olympics</a> will never be equalled. And he did all this with a crazy playfulness and generosity of spirit that made him perhaps the most loved Olympian of all time. The only comparable figure I can think of in 20th century sport is Muhammad Ali – yet Zátopek, unlike Ali, has barely been touched by biographers until now<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/the-running-blog/2016/apr/27/today-we-die-a-little-writing-the-story-of-emil-zatopek">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Running picture of the day: the Marathons des Sables</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/the-running-blog/picture/2016/apr/27/running-picture-of-the-day-the-marathons-des-sables</link>
      <description><p>‘It’s the end of day two at the 31st edition of Morocco’s <a href="http://marathondessables.com/en/">Marathon des Sables</a>. Heat, strong winds and sand storms have blasted the runners, making the 2016 edition one of the toughest in the race’s history.     <item>
      <title>Don't think disabled people aren't interested in cycling – or in proper bike lanes | Isabelle Clement</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/bike-blog/2016/apr/26/dont-think-disabled-people-interested-in-cycling-proper-bike-lanes</link>
      <description><p>Objectors to new bike routes in London and elsewhere often cite the needs of people with disabilities. They’ve missed the point</p><p>Whenever bike infrastructure is debated, it’s never very long before someone objects by saying: “But what happens to people with disabilities if you build cycle lanes?” They have forgotten one very important thing: a lot of disabled people cycle, and benefit even more than most from quick, safe cycle routes.</p><p>Such arguments are seen around the country, but are particularly prominent right now in London, with <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/politics/mayoral-elections">a new mayor being elected next week</a>, and where <a href="http://www.cs11.london/main-objections.html">objectors to proposed cycle superhighways say</a> these will harm disabled people, “who are reliant on their cars”.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/bike-blog/2016/apr/26/dont-think-disabled-people-interested-in-cycling-proper-bike-lanes">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Financial strain on young people is easing, official figures show</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/society/2016/may/11/financial-strain-young-people-easing-office-for-national-statistics</link>
      <description><p>Proportion finding it hard to get by has fallen while more are satisfied with their income, says Office for National Statistics</p><p>Financial pressure on Britain’s young people has eased slightly since <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2009/oct/23/uk-recession-timeline">the depths of the financial crisis</a>, according to the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/uk/office-for-national-statistics">Office for National Statistics</a>.</p><p>The proportion of people aged 16-24 finding it difficult or very difficult to get by fell to 8% in 2013-14, from 15% in 2009-10, the ONS said. Over the same period, young people’s satisfaction with their household income increased to 56% from 51%.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/society/2016/may/11/financial-strain-young-people-easing-office-for-national-statistics">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description>British bouldering star Shauna Coxsey is the early favourite to win a world title this year.       <title>People with more friends have higher pain thresholds, study suggests</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/apr/28/people-with-more-friends-have-higher-pain-thresholds-study-suggests</link>
      <description><p>Link between larger friendship circles and pain tolerance may be down to the way the the brain’s endorphin system has evolved, researchers say</p><p>People with a larger circle of friends are better able to tolerate pain, according to research into the pain thresholds and social networks of volunteers.</p><p>The link is thought to be down a system in the brain that involves endorphins: potent pain-killing chemicals produced by the body that also trigger a sense of wellbeing. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/apr/28/people-with-more-friends-have-higher-pain-thresholds-study-suggests">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Mediterranean-style diet reduces stroke risk in heart patients – study</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/society/2016/apr/25/mediterranean-style-diet-reduces-stroke-risk-in-heart-patients-study</link>
      <description><p>Study of 15,000 people also finds consumption of ‘western’ foods does not increase risk in people with heart disease</p><p>People with heart disease have a lower risk of heart attack and strokes if they eat a Mediterranean-style diet, according to an international study of more than 15,000 people in 39 countries.</p><p>The study is the latest to extol the <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2013/feb/25/mediterranean-diet-strokes-heart-attacks">potential benefits</a> of consuming fruit, vegetables, fish and unrefined foods. It found that for every 100 people with heart disease eating the highest proportion of healthy Mediterranean foods, there were three fewer heart attacks, strokes or deaths compared with 100 people eating the least amount of healthy foods during a three-and-a-half-year period.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/society/2016/apr/25/mediterranean-style-diet-reduces-stroke-risk-in-heart-patients-study">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Time 100: FGM campaigner Jaha Dukureh makes prestigious list</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/apr/21/time-100-fgm-campaigner-jaha-dukureh-makes-prestigious-list</link>
      <description><p>US campaigner made Obama take action on female genital mutilation, and got practice banned in the Gambia</p><p>Anti-FGM campaigner <a href="https://twitter.com/jahaendfgm?lang=en-gb">Jaha Dukureh</a> has been named one of the world’s most influential leaders by<a draggable="true" href="http://time.com/4300131/how-editors-pick-the-time-100/"> Time magazine</a> alongside John Kerry, Angela Merkel, Aung San Suu Kyi, Bernie Sanders and Christine Lagarde.</p><p>Dukureh, the lead campaigner in the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/end-fgm">Guardian’s global media campaign to end female genital mutilation</a>, was honoured in particular for her work in the US and the Gambia but is now campaigning to end the practice worldwide in a generation, using her experiences as a survivor to build public support.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/apr/21/time-100-fgm-campaigner-jaha-dukureh-makes-prestigious-list">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>'I'd struggle without it': Little Stoke park runners on what it means to them</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/apr/15/little-stoke-parkrun-on-what-it-means-to-them</link>
      <description><p>With Saturday’s parkrun cancelled on safety grounds, participants explain its benefits, from mental health to friendship</p><p>Heather Doody could not hold back the tears as she surveyed the playing fields that were to have been the scene of her sporting triumph on Saturday morning. “I’m sorry, it must seem silly to see me crying but this place means so much to me – it feels like a home from home. I’m really sad.”</p><p>Doody was due to complete her 50th parkrun surrounded by the scores of friends she has made in the three-and-a-half years she has been tackling the 5km course at <a href="http://www.parkrun.org.uk/littlestoke/">Little Stoke</a> near Bristol. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/apr/15/little-stoke-parkrun-on-what-it-means-to-them">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/running">Running</category>

      <description><p>Inquest hears financial reasons seemed to be behind decision for a mother to have a natural birth despite her objections. Her baby died days later</p><p>Funding pressures on the NHS are forcing maternity wards to favour natural births over more costly caesareans, risking the lives of some mothers and babies, a senior coroner has warned.</p><p>Andrew Walker said there appeared to be a financial reason for favouring vaginal birth in the June 2015 delivery of Kristian Jaworski, whose mother pleaded for a caesarean after being advised to do so following difficulties with her first birth. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/apr/15/funding-shortages-force-nhs-to-cut-caesareans-coroner-suggests">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Does early retirement mean an early death?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/02/early-earlier-retirement-retire-death-risk-data-research-jobs</link>
      <description><p>The latest research suggests that those ending work younger are more likely to die earlier than those staying in jobs. But is the data clearcut?</p><p>A spot of gardening, going travelling – who hasn’t daydreamed about early retirement? So damn the latest study in the <a href="http://jech.bmj.com/content/early/2016/03/21/jech-2015-207097.short?g=w_jech_ahead_tab">Journal of Epidemiology and Community Health</a> that shows an early retirement can mean less time to enjoy it. </p><p>You might assume the effect was caused by sicker people retiring earlier and dying prematurely, but this study really tries to take that into account. The researchers analysed data from 2,956 people who were part of the <a href="https://www.nia.nih.gov/health/publication/growing-older-america-health-and-retirement-study/preface">Healthy Retirement Study</a> funded by the<a href="https://www.nia.nih.gov/"> National Institute on Aging</a> in America. People were divided into unhealthy and healthy retirees based on whether they said sickness influenced their decision to stop work: about two-thirds were healthy and a third unhealthy. During the 18 years of the study, 12% of the healthy and 25.6% of the unhealthy group died. After taking into account factors such as the healthy group’s better education and finances, they found that healthy retirees who worked a year longer (over the age of 65) had an 11% lower ‘all-cause mortality risk”. Even the unhealthy group reduced their likelihood of dying by 9% if they delayed retirement.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/02/early-earlier-retirement-retire-death-risk-data-research-jobs">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Will a holiday make me happy – and if it does, how long will it last?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/apr/25/will-a-holiday-make-me-happy-and-if-it-does-how-long-will-it-last</link>
      <description><p>The experts are unanimous: holidays do you good, and you should take more of them. Here are the pitfalls to avoid …</p><p> Who doesn’t love a holiday? Apart from my husband, who thinks we should save the money in case our boiler packs up. But many people live for them – a time to recover from work and feel less tired and tense. <a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11020089">A New York study of middle-aged men at high risk of heart disease</a> found that the more vacations they took, the less likely they were to die over a period of nine years. But the reality of a holiday can be different from those adverts showing smiling families on blissful, empty beaches. Do they really make us healthier and happier? <br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/apr/25/will-a-holiday-make-me-happy-and-if-it-does-how-long-will-it-last">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Are my emotions giving me migraines?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/apr/18/are-my-emotions-giving-me-migraines</link>
      <description><p>Experts say no but many people link their attacks to stress or emotional upset</p><p>Want to fly, run your own business or climb Everest? Anything is possible with a virtual reality simulator. Immersive experiences have never been such fun. So, who’s up for experiencing a migraine? Cue Excedrin’s migraine trip, your chance to feel as debilitated, disorientated and distressed as someone who really has the condition. Excedrin makes painkillers (hence its interest in this area) and its representation of the flashing lights and blurry, shifting landscape looks accurate. If only they could bang you on the head and give you the painful throbbing that migraine sufferers feel. At two points in the company’s <a href="http://www.digitaltrends.com/health-fitness/excedrin-migraine-experience/">short online video</a>, a friend or lover turns to a person with migraine and says: “I’m so sorry I doubted you.” So what is it about migraine that makes people feel it’s not real, that its an excuse to bunk off work?</p><p>This week, the New York Times covered migraines in its weekly misconception series by stating: “<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/07/health/debunking-migraine-misconceptions.html?_r=0">Women’s emotions do not cause their migraines</a>.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/apr/18/are-my-emotions-giving-me-migraines">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Should I pay to vaccinate my child against meningitis B?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/apr/11/should-i-pay-to-vaccinate-my-child-against-meningitis</link>
      <description><p>Meningitis is a killer – so immunisation is appealing. But at up to £390 for a full, three-jab course, and with limited effectiveness, it’s a hard choice to make</p><p>Meningitis B is a rare disease, but it could kill your child within hours – the fatality rate is 5-10%. There is a new vaccine, but the <a href="https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/294245/JCVI_Statement_on_MenB.pdf">Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation (JCVI) says it should be restricted</a> to children under a year old. But parents dread meningitis B, and after media reports of the death of two-year-old Faye Burdett in February, more than 820,000 people <a href="https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/108072">signed a petition</a> asking the government to widen the vaccination programme. In the meantime, if you can afford it, should you pay for your child to be vaccinated?</p><p><strong>The solution</strong></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/apr/11/should-i-pay-to-vaccinate-my-child-against-meningitis">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Is a stand-up desk really healthier?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/mar/28/is-a-stand-up-desk-really-healthier</link>
      <description><p>Our sedentary lifestyles are increasingly being blamed for a range of problems. Stand-up and treadmill desks might seem to be the answer, but is it worth shelling out for one?</p><p>Sitting is the new smoking – blamed for increasing the risk of heart disease and cancer, as well as diabetes and obesity. Health guidelines suggest we should spend 150 minutes a week in moderate exercise, but many of us sit down for more than half the working day – email means we don’t even have to get up to talk to anyone. So it is not surprising that there is a gap in the market.</p><p>Stand-up, sit-stand and treadmill desks are all the rage. <a href="http://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/06/10/the-downside-of-treadmill-desks/?_r=0">Google and Microsoft have allegedly bought stacks of treadmill desks</a> – modified treadmill bases attached to work surfaces. <a href="http://www.wired.co.uk/magazine/archive/2014/04/test/walk-life-balance">The manufacturer of TrekDesk says that a treadmill-desk set at a walking speed</a> of 1.5km an hour will burn 2.6 calories a minute. Such energy expenditure does not come cheap: desks cost upwards of £1,000. But do they make people more active and healthier, or are they this year’s corporate gimmick?</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/mar/28/is-a-stand-up-desk-really-healthier">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Should men invest  more in friendships?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/mar/14/are-bromances-good-for-mens-health</link>
      <description><p>Research shows that male rats are less stressed if they spend more time together - the same could be true for humans</p><p>Bonding with other guys may relieve stress in men, according to media reports of <a href="http://news.berkeley.edu/2016/03/03/bromances-may-be-good-for-mens-health/">research published in the journal Neuropsychopharmacology</a> last week. Men who are close with each other have higher levels of oxytocin, popularly known as the “cuddle hormone” <a href="http://www.nature.com/npp/journal/vaop/naam/abs/npp201616a.html">which makes them better at handling stress</a>.</p><p>The research, however, comes from a rat study, and – while rodents are often used as stand-ins for humans, because they similar biological and genetic characteristics – you’d have to assume there are differences. The researchers put pairs of rats in cages together for a week and then put each one in a small confined space for three hours. When they were reunited, the rats were even friendlier than before they had been stressed.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/mar/14/are-bromances-good-for-mens-health">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Is it safe to use talcum powder?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/feb/29/is-it-safe-to-use-talcum-baby-powder-ovarian-cancer-johnson-johnson</link>
      <description><p>The family of a woman in the US who died from ovarian cancer after using Johnson &amp; Johnson baby powder has been awarded damages. So how much of a risk does talc pose?</p><p>What could be more wholesome than Johnson &amp; Johnson’s talcum powder? It&nbsp;is the fragrant way to dry the bits towels can’t reach. <a href="http://www.dailymail.co.uk/health/article-2343974/Women-regularly-use-talcum-powder-increase-risk-ovarian-cancer-24.html" title="">Up to 40% of women</a> may use talc at least occasionally. <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/feb/24/johnson-johnson-72-millon-babuy-talcum-powder-ovarian-cancer" title="">But&nbsp;last week a Missouri jury awarded $72m (£51.5m) in damages</a> to the family of Jackie Fox, who died of ovarian cancer having used the well-known brand of powder for years. More than 1,200 other cases are still waiting to be&nbsp;heard.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/feb/24/johnson-johnson-72-millon-babuy-talcum-powder-ovarian-cancer">Johnson &amp; Johnson to pay $72m in case linking baby powder to ovarian cancer</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/feb/29/is-it-safe-to-use-talcum-baby-powder-ovarian-cancer-johnson-johnson">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Is organic food healthier?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/feb/22/is-organic-food-healthier</link>
      <description><p>A new study has suggested that organic milk might contain higher levels of omega-3 fatty acids. But that doesn’t mean it’s necessarily better for you </p><p><a href="http://journals.cambridge.org/download.php?file=%2FBJN%2FS0007114515005073a.pdf&amp;code=28b1c09a38f38aa1d4063bbf512011e1">After publishing a study showing organic milk has higher levels of omega-3 fatty acids</a> than ordinarily farmed products, Professor Chris Seal braced himself for the backlash. There is nothing like a study highlighting the benefits, or lack thereof, of organic food, to cause a spat. And <a href="http://journals.cambridge.org/download.php?file=%2FBJN%2FS0007114516000349a.pdf&amp;code=078dcb0f73b18b519a5cdd4ecca8b84c">Seal’s study in the British Journal of Nutrition last week </a> (alongside another by him on meat that also shows higher levels of omega-3 fatty acids) certainly has its detractors.</p><p>The fact that the study was funded by the <a href="http://opencharities.org/charities/328369">Sheepdrove Trust</a>, a British charity that supports organic farming, hasn’t helped. Seal says the money paid for analysis only, and that the charity didn’t have any input into the research. The study, a meta-analysis of 196 papers on milk (the other looked at 36 studies on meat), found that organic-grass-fed cows produced milk with 50% more omega-3 fatty acids than that from ordinary dairy cows. These fatty acids are linked to reductions in heart disease. But, while 50% sounds like a lot, full-fat milk is only 4% fat (semi skimmed is 2%) so this translates to an tiny amount more fatty acid in organic milk. Seal argues that if you added in organic cheese and butter, this would increase. But others point out you could get more nutritional benefit buying fruit and vegetables than hoovering up organic dairy produce.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/feb/22/is-organic-food-healthier">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Is it good to be bored (or will it be the death of you)?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/feb/15/is-it-good-to-be-bored-or-will-it-be-the-death-of-you</link>
      <description><p>One study implies that boredom make you likelier to die earlier, but another concludes that it spurs creativity …</p><p>You’re watching a PowerPoint presentation and it’s slide 10 out of 75. Your boss is present, so you can’t risk a&nbsp;quick game of Football Manager 2016 on your phone. But time is stationary. You feel dejected and trapped. You experience something that the Romans documented on the walls of Pompeii: mind-numbing boredom. And you wonder, is being “bored to death” a&nbsp;real thing?</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/feb/15/is-it-good-to-be-bored-or-will-it-be-the-death-of-you">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Should I be screened for depression?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/feb/08/should-i-be-screened-for-depression</link>
      <description><p>Everyone over 18 should be screened for the condition, says a US task force. Meanwhile, UK officials say it should only be done for those at high risk. Who’s right?<br></p><p>Everyone over the age of 18 should be screened for depression, says the <a href="http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=2484345" title="">US Preventive Services Task Force</a> – and the government-appointed body really means everyone. Doctors should ask&nbsp;people if they are sad, tired or distracted – even if they have come in with an ingrown toenail. The rationale for this is that <a href="http://www.webmd.com/depression/news/20100104/americans-with-depression-are-undertreated" title="">only half of those in the US</a> who are depressed get treatment, yet the World Health Organisation projects that by 2020, depression will&nbsp;be the <a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4100461/" title="">second leading cause of disability worldwide</a>.</p><p>Generally, for a condition to be screenable, it should be important, common, treatable and the benefits of screening should outweigh the harms. It shouldn’t have high rates of false positives (diagnosing someone without the condition) or false negatives (missing someone who does have it). The task force says screening for depression fulfills these criteria and that <a href="http://www.nhs.uk/conditions/cognitive-behavioural-therapy/Pages/Introduction.aspx" title="">cognitive behavioural therapy</a> and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs, a type of antidepressant) both reduce symptoms.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/feb/08/should-i-be-screened-for-depression">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Ask Alanis Morissette: since I’ve been ill, I’ve lost contact with many friends</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/06/ask-alanis-morissette-ill-and-lost-friends</link>
      <description><p>All the parts of you – lonely, confident, ill, outgoing – come together to make you who you are. A true friend will recognise that</p><p><strong>A few years ago, I got very ill and I am still suffering the after-effects. I can’t work and now struggle in social situations. I am finding myself incredibly lonely, isolated and depressed. I used to be outgoing and confident, but I have been losing contact with my old friends. I had thought it was because I often turn down invitations due to being unwell, but this week I received a message from one of my oldest friends to tell me that I bring her down and that I need to cheer up. I am heartbroken. I have so much love and friendship to offer, just not in the same way I was able to before. What should I do?</strong></p><p>Sometimes, illnesses or injuries or bouts of depression can leave us feeling completely altered. It makes sense to me that your big life adjustment would have an effect on your social life, and I have a lot of empathy for how hard that can be.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/06/ask-alanis-morissette-ill-and-lost-friends">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>My son’s girlfriend has anorexia and I worry about the effect on him</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/06/my-sons-girlfriend-has-anorexia-and-i-worry-about-the-effect-on-him</link>
      <description>He seems to be coping but I think he’s too young to deal with this complicated illness alone. Annalisa Barbieri advises a reader<p><strong>My adult son is in a long-term relationship with his girlfriend, who has a serious eating disorder. When he first met her she was slim but healthy. Unbeknown to him, she had recently recovered from anorexia. Sadly, over the past few years, the anorexia has returned and she is now extremely frail and underweight. She has recently committed to an inpatient plan but it will be a long process and she is still entrenched in her eating habits and resistant to change, despite having had therapy for almost a year. I am very hopeful that she will be successful, but if she isn’t I worry how this will affect him.</strong></p><p><strong>I know that recovery from anorexia is a long and painful process and inevitably her illness will have a great impact on both their lives. Although her friends and family are supportive, he is the one who sees her every day and has to watch her starve herself, which must be very painful. I don’t often see him on his own and try not to talk about it too much as he seems to prefer to deal with it by pretending it’s not happening and making elaborate travel and holiday plans for the two of them, which seems to me a form of escapism. I suggested he might want therapy or to go to a support group but he says he has a few good friends he can speak to if necessary. </strong></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/06/my-sons-girlfriend-has-anorexia-and-i-worry-about-the-effect-on-him">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>My boyfriend cheated on me but I want to move in | Mariella Frostrup</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/08/my-boyfriend-cheated-on-me-but-i-want-to-move-in-with-him-mariella-frostrup</link>
      <description><p>A woman wants more commitment from her boyfriend. The imbalances in their relationship ring alarm bells for Mariella Frostrup</p><p><strong>The dilemma</strong><em> My boyfriend can’t say “I love you”. He says it will take time. We’ve been going out for a year and a half. For him actions speak louder than words. But he slept with another woman while drunk and travelling six months ago. He was very sorry, and we worked through it and re-established trust and connection. I appreciate his honesty, but at times feel angry. He says that though he felt more lustful passion towards past girlfriends, we have a better chance of staying together because the relationship is not based on superficial unrealistic lust but instead care, fun, respect and growing together. We talk about marriage and babies. I’d like to move in with him, but he’s not ready yet. I’m starting to read this as a sign that he’s not committed to me. Is it normal to have some doubts about a relationship?</em></p><p><strong>Mariella replies </strong>What a catch! Seriously, I’d be having doubts, too. There’s little in your description that suggests to me that he’s in for the long haul. Rationing your allowance when it comes to commitment and desire is hardly the stuff of epic romance. Instead he seems to be doing everything in his power to keep you at arm’s length and in return you’re, what… grateful? I know a good man is hard to find, or certainly was in my searching days, but that doesn’t mean you should settle for slim pickings from the outset. Relationships in the long term may be all about compromise, but in the short term they should deliver satisfaction and joy, not self-doubt.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/08/my-boyfriend-cheated-on-me-but-i-want-to-move-in-with-him-mariella-frostrup">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>I have come out as gay, but no one seems to want to love me</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/06/come-out-as-gay-no-one-wants-to-love-me</link>
      <description><p>I am torn between my religious upbringing and being out, and am disappointed at the emphasis on sex in gay culture. Why can’t someone see the real loving me?</p><p>I am 26 and I came out as gay at the end of last year. I am from a religious background and I feel stuck between two realms and I can’t find the appropriate balance. Seeking a lasting loving relationship for a 26-year-old virgin is not as easy as I thought. With so much preference for everyone to be physical in gay culture, I feel disappointed and even more alone in a foreign country. Dating websites only add to my sorrow and despair. From the religion side, it seems everyone hates me for who I love. I feel I can’t even go back nor move forward, since it seems I am not worth loving, even though I am a talented, loving, caring individual. If someone could see beyond the appearance, they would be see my inner beauty, but no one bothers.</p><p><em>• When leaving a message on this page, please be sensitive to the fact that you are responding to a real person in the grip of a real-life dilemma, who wrote to Private Lives asking for help, and may well view your comments here. Please consider especially how your words or the tone of your message could be perceived by someone in this situation, and be aware that comments that appear to be disruptive or disrespectful to the individual concerned will be removed.</em></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/06/come-out-as-gay-no-one-wants-to-love-me">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/relationships">Relationships</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/lifeandstyle">Life and style</category>
      <pubDate>Fri, 06 May 2016 11:00:24 GMT</pubDate>
      <guid>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/06/come-out-as-gay-no-one-wants-to-love-me</guid>
      <media:content width="140" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/427aa6fc7b9f9b26d2d3b592cbd7aef7a26e6b31/0_192_5760_3456/5760.jpg?w=140&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=6187810068febee125c3d0257dd06ba2">
        <media:credit scheme="urn:ebu">Photograph: Westend61/Getty Images/Westend61</media:credit>
      </media:content>

    <item>
      <title>Ask Alys Fowler: can I replant moss from a roof under a tree?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/gardening-blog/2016/may/07/can-i-replant-moss-under-a-tree-alys-fowler</link>
      <description><p>By far the quickest solution would be just to put the moss on the compost heap, but replanting may be worth a punt </p><p><strong>I have cleared a huge amount of moss from a roof. Can I add it to a plot under a large tree that keeps the ground beneath it quite dry?</strong><br>Well, the moss may take root and give you a mossy groundcover, but then again, it may not: it all depends on what kind of moss you have. If the moss is unhappy, it will just break down, adding a little more organic matter to the soil; it may or may not look interesting as it does this.&nbsp;</p><p>Equally, it may end up being one of those things you endlessly have to explain: “What’s that moss doing there in odd piles?” “Oh, that’s my moss experiment.” To be honest, by far the quickest solution would be just to put it on the compost heap, where it will quickly break down once in the dark.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/gardening-blog/2016/may/07/can-i-replant-moss-under-a-tree-alys-fowler">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>My wife prefers masturbation to having sex with me</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/09/my-wife-prefers-masturbation-to-having-sex-with-me</link>
      <description>I feel devastated by her physical rejection of me and have tried to get her to talk about it or go to see a counsellor, but she refuses<p><strong>My wife prefers masturbation to sex&nbsp;with me. This is devastating to me&nbsp;and my self esteem. There are always a long list of excuses of why she doesn’t feel like talking about it. She has cheated on me a few times, too, and I have forgiven her but never&nbsp;forgotten. I brought up going to&nbsp;see somebody to talk about it, but she won’t. What should I do?</strong></p><p>Your wife is giving you a great deal of unspoken information, but it is hard for you to take in, probably because it’s&nbsp;painful. There must be specific reasons why you stay in a marriage with someone who not only rejects you&nbsp;sexually, but also allows you to be&nbsp;aware of her alternative sexual choices. If the positives of the relationship outweigh the negatives, then – like many other people in a similar bind – you may decide to continue. Plenty of people choose a sexless marriage, which is usually fine&nbsp;if that’s what both partners desire.&nbsp;But others put up with a situation such&nbsp;as yours because, deep&nbsp;down, they do not believe they can ever have&nbsp;a fair and equitable relationship. Think&nbsp;carefully about what you truly want and need. How&nbsp;important is sex to you? How important is having sex with <em>her</em> to you? Ask that she respect your perfectly valid and urgent need to talk&nbsp;this through. Given the impasse between you, you have a right to insist&nbsp;on counselling.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/09/my-wife-prefers-masturbation-to-having-sex-with-me">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description>Is there any chance of getting my money from I Love Cashback?<p><strong>Last year I signed up to cashback website I Love Cashback, which offered cash rewards if you used its site as a portal to various online shopping sites.     <item>
      <title>Will higher rate stamp duty apply if my ex wants to buy me out?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/money/2016/may/12/will-higher-rate-stamp-duty-apply-if-my-ex-wants-to-buy-me-out</link>
      <description><p>Confusion over new rules and how they apply to purchasing full stake in part-owned property is affecting my chances of buying a place of my own</p><p><strong>Q: </strong>I desperately need some advice on the new stamp duty rules. My boyfriend and I split up last year but we own a property together, bought in 2010, which is our primary residence. He has a buy-to-let property which is nothing to do with me (and neither of us have lived there) that he’s owned for 10 years, bought with inheritance from his grandparents. We are currently in the process of him buying me out of my half of our property so that I can buy a place of my own. </p><p>Our solicitors are saying that he will have to pay the higher rate of stamp duty land tax on this purchase, even though he is not buying a new property and this will remain his main residence. This is an increase of £7,000 on the stamp duty he was expecting to pay and he isn’t sure he can afford it, which is putting my house purchase in jeopardy. Everyone seems unsure of what is correct in this situation and we’re both extremely confused. Surely the stamp duty change was to stop people purchasing second homes, not from buying additional interest in the property they already own? Neither of us can quite believe that he will have to pay over £10,000 in stamp duty to purchase half of the house he already owns and lives in. <strong>SS</strong></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/money/2016/may/12/will-higher-rate-stamp-duty-apply-if-my-ex-wants-to-buy-me-out">Continue reading...</a></description>
